story:
Story of My Book

My Heart of Rice explores how food, family, and love has shaped and motivated my sense of culture, identity, and self-discovery.

My name is Ashley Lanuza and I am the author of My Heart of Rice. I wrote this book because I wanted to share my experiences as a Filipino-American and the narratives I have read and heard about from my peers and university research. Concepts that occur in the community, such as community conditions and histories, were not available to me until I attended UCLA- and if it was hidden from me at a young age, it is probably hidden from today's youth, as well. I want to retell these narratives to emphasize unity in our shared experiences and accept the differences in our unique details; moreover, to remind every reader of how familial love has shaped our love for ourselves.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover how your personal life and memories intersect with the bigger picture found in history and society. I hope to instill the same sort of passion and excitement that I have for family, culture, and self-discovery in you. And then ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to guide you in your search for your roots and sociocultural identity.

In this book, you'll learn about the love of family and redefining the words “Filipino-American”:

  • The relationship between my grandfather and I, emphasized by the Filipino food he cooked, and how that shaped how I saw myself in society
  • The realization that not all Filipinos/Filipino-Americans share the same experiences- just similar ones, and that the unique details don't invalidate your own narrative
  • The research on Filipino-American history and the community conditions we tend to face as a result of our cultural values and identity

You will love this book if you love poetry, interested in the Filipino-American experience, or love relatable literature that describes the influences of family and society on an individual.

My Heart of Rice is a non-fiction book that speaks to Filipino Americans and non Filipino-Americans who are looking at unique narratives, erased histories, and unspoken community patterns.

The Book - My Heart of Rice

The book is written in 5 Parts....so far....

Part 1 discusses childhood- the developing relationship I have with traditional Filipino food through dinners and grocery store visits. It also explores micro-aggressions I experienced in elementary school, along with introducing a character who started to influence my identity with their own Hispanic culture.

Part 2 looks at high school, where I was mostly the “Filipino Club” on campus. It explores my relationship with Hispanic peers and an attempt to assimilate with a culture similar- yet still different- than my own.

Part 3 explores the cultural division I felt in submersing myself with Filipino/Filipino American peers, communities that I was not accustomed to and where I sometimes felt “not Filipino enough.”

Part 4 discusses my discovery about histories and community conditions I was oblivious to prior to college. Through a fictional first-person perspective, I take on key Filipino characters in history- such as the first Filipino settlers in 1700s Louisiana, Filipino immigrants in Stockton, California, the unionizing Filipino farmworkers in Delano, and the concept of the Balikbayan boxes and Overseas Filipino Workers. I also discuss community conditions, such as Filipinos-Americans’ pressure into entering the STEM field, the immigrant experience, and defining what it means to be a community activist. This section is heavy with research, rhetorical questions, and discovery. Its the part that pushed me to make this book in the first place.

Part 5 deals with the aftermath of what I've learned. At this point, I've accepted my differences from my peers, and find similarities that don't always have to pinpoint back to being Filipino. From here, I discuss "What now?" in a sort of meta, fourth wall way, you can say that publishing this book is the answer to my dilemma. Or maybe, there's more to it. However, it all goes back to the food, the love, and the family I have, and how much that has influenced who I am, and who I want to be, today.

What I Need & What You'll Get

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript in February 2020
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to make help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this upcoming winter.
When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.

I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:
  • A personal, handwritten thank you note & author's signature for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“with Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experiences of writing my book
  • And more..

About the Author

Ashley Lanuza is a senior at UCLA studying Psychology, Film, and Asian American studies. This LA native has published articles with the Mid-Valley News, the Daily Bruin, and Odyssey. Her career focus, however, is in script development, and she hopes to develop and produce film and television that pushes for diverse storytelling and representation.

Ashley wrote this book to share her story and the narratives she's heard from her peers and read about during her UCLA studies. Her passion for telling untold stories started at a young age, and has prompted her dream of becoming a published author. Who knew that dreams can become a reality, too?

Although voted “Samabaddie” by her UCLA peers in 2016, Ashley is anything but “bad” (what does that mean, anyway?!). She can go on an hour-long analytical discussion (see rant) about music, literature, and movies (especially movies), bore you to death about it, and then suggest to get ice cream afterwards. You'll also probably be walking the entire time with her because she's happiest when “exploring” (see wasting time aimlessly walking around small towns and big cities).

For more information you can connect with Ashley at ashley.lanuza@gmail.com and Ashley Nicole on Facebook and @ashlanuza_ on Instagram.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
  • Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #myheartofrice and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.
  • You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page
  • Please share my book to 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

Thank you so much of all of your love and support!

Love, Ashley Lanuza

story:
Connecting Palestinian Realities to Western Audiences 

A fundraiser for Palestine Deep Dive

This is a pivotal moment to reshape the media landscape, enhancing connections between Palestinian realities and Western audiences.

With one click, you can do just that – invest in a bold and unique media alternative strengthening the flow of news from Palestine to the West which respects the centrality of Palestinian voices, helping to bring them further into the mainstream while also nurturing the young journalists of tomorrow.

 

A Pivotal Moment to Build:

Right now we are witnessing a shift. A shift driven by decades of tireless grassroots advocacy, brave frontline reporting, network building and campaigning to bring us to this pivotal moment. In a matter of weeks the struggle for Palestinian rights and justice broke through into mainstream public awareness, albeit under dire circumstances, with Palestinian voices finally starting to be given some space to present their realities to the world across various media.  

But while Palestinians might well have been given more space on the airwaves in recent weeks compared to previously, we know this may well be another rapidly closing window only open during Israel’s latest assaults on Gaza. And unsurprisingly we’ve already seen attempts to firmly close the lid on news from Palestine reaching the wider world across the media landscape since May. 

Journalism Under Attack

In many places around the world today journalists are increasingly under attack but this is especially so in Israel/Palestine. The International Federation of Journalists report that at least 46 Palestinian journalists have been killed by Israel since 2000.

And in the last couple of months alone, at least two Palestinian journalists have been killed and more than one hundred injured. We’ve witnessed footage of Al Jazeera’s Givara Budeiri being assaulted and arrested by Israeli soldiers, among others, while attempting to report on events in East Jerusalem and we’ve seen the bombardment and destruction of whole media offices belonging to the Associated Press, Al Jazeera and others in Gaza by Israeli warplanes. And it is not just professional journalists who are under attack. 

With the nature of journalism changing before our eyes with technology, young people especially are able to share stories widely before official outlets get hold of them. In Gaza “everyone now is learning to be a journalist” Raed Shakshak, Outreach Coordinator for We Are Not Numbers, told us on our live show whilst under bombardment in May. 

With the popularity of smartphones and their ability to instantly share footage and ‘go live’ on social media platforms, this has had a dramatic impact on awakening the world to Palestinian realities. But as Mona Shtaya and Mariam Barghouti exposed in our live show “Israel’s War on Media”, attempts to stymy the flow of news from Palestine through a ‘blackout’ extend into the sphere of social media too. In addition to online censorship, young people with large social media platforms also face intimidation, violence and arrest, as seen with the recent arrest of our live show guest Mohammed El-Kurd.

In the face of attempted media blackouts, now is a vital time to shine the light on Israel/Palestine brighter than ever before. By amplifying the work of fearless journalists and a new generation of brave Palestinian voices we help to strengthen the flow of news from Palestine reaching the West.

We are Asking for your Support 

Palestine Deep Dive is a bold new media alternative shining a fresh spotlight on journalism surrounding Israel/Palestine, connecting Palestinian realities with Western audiences. We seek to educate and empower a growing audience concerned with human rights, democracy, freedom of speech, justice and equality, which must be heard now more than ever.

We host world-leading experts and voices from the ground alike in regular live shows presenting the latest news from Palestine coupled with in-depth analysis. 

Since April 2020 we have produced 35 live shows, with over 60% of our guests being Palestinian. Our recent shows have included DeepDives into the global arms trade with Israel and “Israel’s War on the Media” as well as hearing live from young Palestinians whilst enduring bombardment in Gaza and undergoing forced eviction in East Jerusalem. 

We also produced the first English-language video interview with Loay Elbasyouni, the Palestinian lead electrical engineer on NASA’s Mars Ingenuity Helicopter, and utilised our international media network to further amplify his voice around the world. 

 

And we deliver news daily straight to your inbox through our newsletter, Deep Dive Daily. Our experienced editors curate vital stories, quality journalism and ‘Going Viral’ clips before they hit the headlines each day. We have curated over 500 newsletters since January 2021 and with thousands of subscribers, our rapidly growing audience consists of policy makers, journalists, campaigners and individuals around the world.

 

Finally, producing meaningful journalism today also means strengthening the voices of tomorrow. Palestine Deep Dive will do this in the short term by producing a range of online journalism training workshops for young Palestinians in Gaza this month. Our ultimate goal, with your support, is to establish a scholarship programme for young Palestinian journalists to study in the UK or USA. By starting a fundraising campaign now we believe our first participants can attend a university course in 2022.  

Thank you for continuing to recognise the work we are doing - we are extremely grateful to all our show participants and here are some of their recent comments on the importance of our work:  

“Palestinian voices and the voices of those advocating for Palestine all too often excluded from the mainstream media . Platforms such as Palestine Deep Dive seek to address this and undertake valuable work in providing a platform where these voices can be amplified and the facts of the ongoing oppression of the Palestinian people be brought into the public domain.”

~ Ben Jamal (Director of the Palestine Solidarity Campaign)

“Although new on the scene, Palestine Deep Dive already fills a gap in crucial information about Palestine, creatively curating the politics of the day as well as cultural events to ensure that the cause of freedom is firmly front and center in world affairs”

~ Nadia Hijab (co-founder of Al-Shabaka: The Palestinian Policy network; co-founder of the US Campaign for Palestinian Rights)

“News is what someone somewhere wants to suppress, however, Palestine DeepDive relentless goes for the truth... and that is the greatest news.”

~ Najwa Najjar (Award winning Palestinian writer and film director)

Palestine Deep Dive is a unique platform dedicated to amplifying the Palestinian voice and to creating an alternative, more equitable media channel on Palestine and Israel. PDDʼs uniqueness stems largely from the diversity of its approach, while maintaining the integrity of its message. While many other platforms claim to serve the same purpose, PDD is truly independent and is entirely motivated by its foundersʼ belief in offering a safe environment for essential voices on Palestine, while fully adhering to the principles of free speech, a lacking quality in mainstream media coverage of the subject. PDD deserves our encouragement and full support.

~ Dr. Ramzy Baroud (Journalist, author, editor and founder of the Palestine Chronicle)

“PDD fills a void in global media, centering the voices of scholars, activists, and policymakers who offer a nuanced and measured take on the news of the moment. Their emphasis on featuring Palestinian experts is unmatched among most outlets covering Israel and Palestine, and I look forward to continuing to see their efforts grow in the coming years.”

~ Dr. Yara Asi (PhD, Public Affairs. Global health, war, aid, & development)

"Palestine Deep Dive is a dynamic, compelling media platform, combining original, informed content with passion, and powerful voices."

~ Ben White (Journalist, author)
